div.p: SMITHERY, a ſmith’s ſhop; alſo the art of a ſmith, by which iron is wrought into any ſhape by means of fire, hammering, filing, & c.

SMITING-line, in a ſhip, is a ſmall rope faſtened to the mizen-yard-arm, below at the deck, and is always furled up with the mizen-ſail, even to the upper end of the yard, and thence it comes down to the poop. Its uſe is to looſe the mizen-ſail without striking down the yard, which is eaſily done, becauſe the mizen-ſail is furled up only with rope-yarns ; and therefore when this rope is pulled hard, it breaks all the rope-yarns, and ſo the ſail falls down of itſelf. The ſailor’s phraſe is, ſmite the mizen (whence this rope takes its name), that is, hale by this rope that the ſail may fall down.
